intro: Acer tschonoskii subsp. koreanum, commonly known as the Korean maple, is a deciduous tree native to Korea and parts of northeastern China. It typically grows to a height of 10–15 meters, featuring a rounded crown and smooth, grey bark. The leaves are palmately lobed, with a serrated margin and a bright green upper surface. In autumn, the foliage turns vibrant shades of red and orange, making it a striking ornamental plant. It prefers well-drained soil and full sun to partial shade, thriving in temperate climates.
